bibl.title: Letter from William S. Thayer to Laura Armistead Carter, April 14, 1926

div1.p: Thayer discusses the influence of Carter's and Finlay's work on Reed and Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from William S. Thayer to Laura Armistead Carter, April 14, 1926

opener.dateline:
W. S. THAYER, M.D.
1208 EUTAW PLACE
BALTIMORE, MD.
April 14, 1926.

div1.p:
I have been much interested in reading the correspondence of General
Cumming and Dr. Ravenel. This matter is very clear in my mind. Reed, of
course, was a warm friend of mine and with Lazear I had been working for
a year before he went to Cuba on the study of mosquitoes and in the culti-
vation of the malarial parasite (tertian) in Anopheles maculipennis. At
the time when Lazear went to Cuba he was the one member of the Commission
who was relatively familiar with the anatomy and habits, genera and species
of our common mosquitoes. I am sure that when Reed laid out his work he had
in mind the study of the mosquito question and at the same time, of course,
he was more or less familiar with Finlay's work, but I am also sure that at
that time he was not particularly impressed by it. I knew at the time that
it was Lazear who first called to Reed's attention the significance of Car-
ter's observations on the incubation period of yellow fever and I knew that
it was this circumstance that turned them directly to the mosquito studies
and back to the observations of Finlay. This I was aware of before their
publication through my communications with Lazear and Mrs. Lazear. Much
later Dr. H. R. Carter told, as recounted by Miss Carter, of his having show-
ed his publication to Lazear and of Lazear's instant recognition of its sig-
nificance.

These, it seems to me, are simply questions of fact. In a broader sense
it detracts from the credit of nobody's work. Reed and Lazear would have
been the last to have made little of Finlay's important observations and
have, it seems to me, given him full credit. But the fact is that rightly
or wrongly these observations had not impressed them greatly (They were sug-
gestive but not convincing.) until the revelations of Carter's observations
as to the incubation period convinced them of the probability that there was
an intermediate host, that the intermediate host, because of the close analo-
gy with Ross's work on malaria with which Lazear was steeped, and of the ob-
servations and hypotheses of Finlay, was in all probability, a mosquito.

On re-studying Finlay's work they naturally selected the mosquito which
he had pointed out as the probable infecting agent. That this was the course
of events I am as sure as I can be.
